summary: This document is a chain of emails from June 2020 between personnel at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and FBI forensic examiners (NY CART). The emails discuss significant delays and logistical challenges in processing, transferring, and reviewing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The correspondence reveals technical issues with data formats, staffing shortages, and the complexity of handling evidence from numerous devices. This document is an email chain from February 2020 discussing the logistical challenges of processing and tracking the massive volume of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the Virgin Islands. It highlights the scale of the evidence (over a million documents, dozens of devices) and the lack of organization in the data transfers, prompting a request for a coordinated meeting and a tracking system.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The primary FBI point of contact coordinating the forensic examination and data transfer of digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties. They discuss technical challenges, staffing issues, and timelines.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Appears as the sign-off on the email, indicating they are part of the case team handling the evidence and are seeking clarity on what materials have been received.

events.title: Staffing Reduction Impacts Timeline
events.description: The FBI NY CART coordinator reports being reduced to one day a week of work, stretching out the evidence processing timeline by a factor of five.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

events.title: Search of Epstein's Residences
events.description: Search warrants were executed at Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, and upon his person at arrest, resulting in the seizure of numerous digital devices.

events.title: Prior Property Search
events.description: Reference to a July 2007 search of one of Epstein's properties, from which hard drives were found and copied in the 2019 evidence.

events.title: Email Coordination on Epstein Evidence
events.description: An email is sent to coordinate a meeting about the massive and disorganized digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties, noting over a million documents have been received.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: Initial Email on Evidence Tracking Issues
events.description: An earlier email is sent raising concerns about the inability to track which Epstein search warrant materials are new versus previously received, due to a lack of labeling.

locations: The Island (likely referring to Little St. James, Epstein's private island)
keyFacts: The FBI was processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Epstein's New York and U.S. Virgin Islands properties, including phones, tablets, loose media, cameras, DVRs, servers, laptops, and desktop computers.

Significant technical and logistical challenges were hindering the review, including incompatible data formats, an inability to link emails to attachments, and problems loading files into the Relativity e-discovery platform used by prosecutors.
The COVID-19 pandemic and related staffing reductions (down to one day a week for examiners) caused major delays in the evidence processing timeline.
Evidence included items from a prior July 2007 search of an Epstein property, specifically 9 IDE hard drives that were copies of 3 original drives.
The correspondence highlights the immense scale and complexity of the digital forensic investigation following Epstein's arrest.
Digital evidence seized from Epstein's New York mansion included approximately 40 storage devices (computers, hard drives, thumb drives) and at least 60+ CDs.
Evidence from the Virgin Islands property included more than 25 devices, including multiple servers or server racks.
The total volume of materials received was described as 'well over a million documents,' with one folder alone containing more than 600,000 items.
Investigators expressed significant difficulty in tracking what evidence had been previously received and processed due to a lack of a proper identification or labeling system.
The case team was planning to be in California the week following the email, with coordination efforts aimed for the first week of March 2020.
